scenarios.question: Describe the correct aircraft emergency procedure below 1,500 ft (500m) .

choices.A:
If aircraft is stable, stay with the aircraft and follow directions from the pilot. Ensure 
the student is seated and seat belted
choices.C:
Assure the student that everything is going 
to be okay
choices.B:
If aircraft has catastrophic damage, attach as many attachment points as the 
situation will allow, starting with the upper 
left hook. Hold the student with right arm and legs if needed, exit and immediately 
deploy the reserve

scenarios.rationale: Below 1500 ft: stay with stable aircraft; catastrophic damage: attach student, exit, deploy reserve.

scenarios.question: Describe the correct aircraft emergency procedure between 1,500ft (500m) and 4000ft (1200m) .

choices.A: Attach the student, exit the aircraft and immediately deploy the reserve
choices.C: Stay in the aircraft and land with the airplane
choices.B:
Assure to the student that everything is 
going to be okay

scenarios.rationale: 1500–4000 ft: attach student, exit, immediately deploy reserve.

scenarios.question: Describe the correct aircraft emergency procedure above 4,000 ft (1,200 m).

choices.B: Stay with the aircraft and land with the airplane
choices.C: Attach the student, exit, set and inflate the drogue, then release drogue

scenarios.rationale: >4000 ft: attach student, exit, set/inflate drogue, then release to main.

scenarios.question: Describe the correct cutaway procedure for a partial malfunction.

choices.B: Remove RSL, cutaway, ensure separation, deploy reserve
choices.C: Strip the right, track and pull reserve

scenarios.rationale: Partial malfunction: cutaway → ensure riser separation → deploy reserve.

scenarios.question:
What is the correct procedure for a premature deployment of your main (horseshoe) in which you cannot 
deploy the drogue?

choices.C: Open Container with Drogue Issues EP

scenarios.rationale: Container open and drogue issues are handled under the Open-Container-with-Drogue-Issues EP.

scenarios.question:
Which is the correct response to an inflated drogue (“in tow”) that does not release the main pin during a 
main canopy deployment attempt?

choices.C: Open Container with Drogue Issues EP

scenarios.rationale: Inflated drogue that doesn’t pull the pin leaves the container closed → treat as Total Malfunction.

scenarios.question: What is the correct response to an uninflated drogue right after drogue set ?

choices.A:
Wait 6 -8 seconds for drogue to inflate, if it 
does not, pull drogue release
choices.C:
Wait 6 -8 seconds for drogue to inflate, if it 
does not, Partial Malfunction EP
choices.B:
Wait 6-8 seconds for drogue to inflate, if it 
does not, Total Malfunction EP
choices.D:
Dip a shoulder to get clean air into your 
burble

scenarios.rationale: If drogue does not inflate, wait ~6–8 s, then pull a drogue release.

scenarios.question: What is the correct response to a collapsed drogue in tow ?

choices.C: Open Container with Drogue Issues EP

scenarios.rationale: Collapsed drogue in tow (container open) → open-container-with-drogue-issues branch.

scenarios.question: What should you do if you accidentally pull the drogue release handle before you deploy the drogue?

choices.C: Total Malfunction EP

scenarios.rationale: If drogue release was pulled before deploying the drogue, set the drogue.

scenarios.question:
What should you do if you can’t extract the drogue from its pouch after your second attempt within 10 
seconds after exit?

choices.C: Open Container with Drogue Issues EP

scenarios.rationale: If you can’t extract the drogue after two attempts and ~10 s, go to Total Malfunction (reserve).

scenarios.question: What should you do if the bridle wraps around you or your passenger and you can’t clear it ?

choices.C: Open Container with Drogue Issues EP

scenarios.rationale: Bridle wraps on you/student and cannot be cleared → treat as third-party entanglement.

scenarios.question: What is the correct response if the drogue does not release after pulling left drogue release, right drogue release, and both together? Conduct…

choices.C: Open Container with Drogue Issues EP

scenarios.rationale: No release from either drogue handle → main tray won’t open → Total Malfunction.

scenarios.question: Explain the correct way to pull your reserve or cutaway handles free of their Velcro pockets.

choices.A:
Peel upward and outward, the n pull 
downward
choices.C: Peel using both hands

scenarios.rationale: Peel upward and outward to break Velcro, then pull downward.

scenarios.question: What would you do if your left shoulder was dislocated, and you needed to pull your reserve?

choices.A:
Pull the reserve handle using your right 
hand
choices.C:
Nothing, the AAD will activate at 2000ft 
(600m)
choices.B:
Ask the student to pull the reserve handle 
for you
choices.D:
Disconnect RSL and pull upwards using 
the RSL Lanyard to deploy the reserve

scenarios.rationale: With left shoulder dislocation, use RSL lanyard method to deploy the reserve.

scenarios.question: What is the primary cause of tandem incidents that result in a fatality ?

choices.C: Instructor error

scenarios.rationale: Most common factor is instructor error.

scenarios.question: What is the procedure for a videographer caught in your drogue bridle?

choices.C: Open Container with Drogue Issues EP

scenarios.rationale: Videographer trapped in bridle is third-party entanglement EP.

scenarios.question:
In an entanglement scenario where both jumpers have no good canopy and are below 3000ft (900m) , what 
should the entangled parachutists do ?

choices.C:
The higher jumper initiates cutaway first, 
followed by the lower jumper
choices.B:
The lower jumper initiates cutaway to 
increase separation
choices.D:
Both jumpers disconnect RSLs and 
attempt to climb above the other

scenarios.rationale: Below 3000 ft with no good canopies: lower jumper cuts away first to increase separation.

scenarios.question: What is the proper instructor action in a high wind landing with no ground assistance available?

choices.C: Have the student sit back in the harness

scenarios.rationale: In high winds without help: collapse by letting one toggle up and hand-over-hand the other; if not possible, disconnect RSL and cutaway.

scenarios.question: What can be done, after opening the main canopy, to make the student’s harness more comfortable?

choices.C: Have the student sit back in the harness

scenarios.rationale: Post-opening comfort: loosen chest strap, reposition leg straps, and have student sit back.

scenarios.question: The Side Lateral Connections must be detached, loosened, and reattached where ?

choices.C: They should never be detached
choices.D: There is no need to reattach anywhere

scenarios.rationale: Side laterals must be reattached onto the student harness.

scenarios.question: What is your decision altitude?
scenarios.rationale: Decision altitude ≈ 3500 ft (per SOP; configurable).

scenarios.question: What is your ‘do not cutaway below’ altitude?
scenarios.rationale: Do not cutaway below ≈1500 ft AGL.
